block.p: As Truce in Mideast Fails, Violent Clashes Resume A cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians crumbled within hours when rioting and gun battles flared anew throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip and in Arab towns in Israel. Israeli commanders said they believed that the violence had not yet reached its peak.

As Truce in Mideast Fails, Violent Clashes Resume A cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians crumbled within hours when rioting and gun battles flared anew throughout the West Bank and Gaza Strip and in Arab towns in Israel. Israeli commanders said they believed that the violence had not yet reached its peak.
Human rights groups and some countries, including the United States, criticized Israel after reports of excessive force by troops.
Serbs Promise a Crackdown The Yugoslav government warned the opposition of ''special measures'' and prosecutions for those behind a spreading strike intended to oust President Slobodan Milosevic.
Suharto's Son Seeks Pardon The youngest son of the former Indonesian president, Suharto, admitted corruption and asked for clemency to avoid an 18-month prison sentence imposed by the Supreme Court.

A Shake-Up in Taiwan Prime Minister Tang Fei resigned, citing poor health. Mr. Tang, on the job for less than five months, announced his decision after a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian. Mr. Tang's deputy, Chang Chun-hsiung, was chosen to succeed him.

Lithuania to Return Scrolls Parliament voted to return hundreds of Torah scrolls to Jewish communities around the world, ending years of debate over the texts. About 370 texts, mostly fragments, were recovered in Lithuania after the Holocaust and were hidden away during the decades of Soviet rule.

Baseball Playoffs The Seattle Mariners beat the Chicago White Sox, 7-4, in the first game of the three-of-five-game American League series. In the N.L., the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Atlanta Braves, 7-5. The Mets open against the San Francisco Giants today.

Bush and Gore Face Off In First Campaign Debate Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush met in Boston for their first presidential debate, arguing over issues that included taxes, health care and foreign policy.

More Visas for High-Tech Congress passed a bill to increase significantly the number of visas for educated foreigners who temporarily fill specialized American jobs, largely in high-tech industries. The president is expected to sign it.

Consensus on Drunken Driving House and Senate negotiators agreed to push for a tough national standard for drunken driving -- a blood-alcohol level of 0.08 percent -- threatening to withhold some federal highway aid from states that balk.
Use of Sobriety Checkpoints The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether the police can add a trained dog to sobriety checkpoints to check cars for drugs.

Senate Hearing on Lee Case Former government officials disagreed over whether Wen Ho Lee became the subject of an espionage investigation because of his ethnicity, and scientists debated the significance of the nuclear information he downloaded at Los Alamos.
HUD Takes Over Texas Agency The Department of Housing and Urban Development seized control of a public housing authority in Texas, citing a pattern of discriminatory abuses dating to the 1960's.

Child Born to Save Sister American scientists used genetic tests to help a couple have a baby with the exact traits needed to provide a cell transplant to treat their seriously ill 6-year-old daughter.
Judge Presses Auction House A federal judge questioned Christie's good faith in refusing to answer some questions and ordered it to respond or face possible sanctions.

Suffolk Votes to Create Crime of Cell Phone D.W.T. The Suffolk County Legislature voted to make driving while using a hand-held cell phone punishable by a $150 fine, unless the phone has an earpiece or works as a speakerphone.

Lennon's Killer Denied Parole Mark David Chapman, 45, serving 20 years to life for murdering John Lennon in 1980, was denied parole after a hearing before the State Parole Board. He can reapply in two years.

Officer Linked to Drug Ring A city police officer, Homero Zapata, 36, and his wife, Liliana Lopez-Zapata, 31, were arrested and charged with helping to launder more than $1 million for Colombian drug lords.

Priority on Church Finances The new archbishop of New York, Edward M. Egan, hired a longtime former aide, Bernard E. Reidy, a layman who helped overhaul the finances of Archbishop Egan's former diocese, Bridgeport.

Parent Views on Sex Education A survey suggests that most parents want schools to offer more sex education to teenagers, including information on abstinence as well as birth control, and sexually transmitted disease, abortion and orientation.
Florida Vouchers Upheld A Florida appellate court ruled that the state could use taxpayer-financed vouchers for students in poor-performing schools who cannot afford private-school tuition.

Superintendent Under Fire Four of the nine members of Brooklyn's Community School Board 15 want Chancellor Harold O. Levy to consider firing the district's superintendent, Francis J. DeStefano, and several deputies following accusations of financial mismanagement and cuts in services in the district.
Fed Holds Rates, for Now The Fed held interest rates steady, but warned that low unemployment and high oil prices could still lead to a jump in inflation.
The Nasdaq fell 113.07 points, or 3.2 percent, to 3,455.83, and the S.& P. 500 lost 9.77 points, to 1,426.46, but the Dow rose 19.61, to 10,719.74.

Time Warner-EMI Deal Weighed European regulators are considering approving a $20 billion deal that would merge Time Warner's music division with EMI, which would lift a big barrier in Europe to the Time Warner-America Online deal.

Takeover Deal in Trouble Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst and Bear, Stearns were said to be having trouble financing a $2.85 billion takeover bid for the Johns Manville building materials company because of concern over Manville's earnings.
Editorials: The first presidential debate; Balkan machinations; restoring Wolfe. Columns: Paul Krugman.
